Package io.permazen.annotation

Annotation Interface JCompositeIndex

@Repeatable(JCompositeIndexes.class) @Retention(RUNTIME) @Target({ANNOTATION_TYPE,TYPE}) @Documented public @interface JCompositeIndex
Java annotation that defines a composite index.

A composite index is an index on two or more fields (to define a single-field index, see JField.indexed(). All fields participating in a composite index must be (a) simple and (b) not a sub-field of a complex field.

The class or interface does not have to be @PermazenType-annotated; annotations are "inherited" and so apply to all @PermazenType-annotated sub-types.

@JCompositeIndex is a repeatable annotation.

Uniqueness Constraints

Uniqueness constraints are supported, and their enforcement is handled in the same way as for uniqueness constraints on simply indexed fields (see @JField.unique()). A uniqueness constriant on a composite index means each combination of field values must be unique to a single object. Specific field value combinations may be excluded from the uniqueness constraint by specifying the corresponding comma-separated String-encoded tuples in uniqueExclude().
See Also:
  • PermazenType
  • JField.indexed()

    Modifier and Type
    Optional Element
    Description

  • Element Details

    • name

      String name
      The name of this index.

      The name must be unique among all other indexes and simple fields in a Java model type.

      Returns:
      the index name

    • fields

      String[] fields
      The names of the indexed fields, in the desired order. At least two fields must be specified.
      Returns:
      the names of the indexed fields

    • storageId

      int storageId
      Storage ID for this index.

      Normally this value is left as zero, in which case a value will be automatically assigned.

      Otherwise, the value should be positive and unique within the schema.

      Returns:
      this index's storage ID, or zero for automatic assignment
      Default:
      0

    • unique

      boolean unique
      Require each object's field combination to be unique among all types to which this annotation applies.

      This property creates an implicit uniqueness validation constraint.

      The constraint will be checked any time normal validation is performed on an object. More precisely, a uniqueness constraint behaves like a JSR 303 validation constraint with groups() = { Default.class, UniquenessConstraints.class }. Therefore, uniqueness constraints are included in default validation, but you can also validate only uniqueness constraints via myobj.revalidate(UniquenessConstraints.class).

      Returns:
      whether the composite index's field values should be unique
      See Also:
      • uniqueExclude()
      • UniquenessConstraints
      Default:
      false

    • uniqueExclude

      String[] uniqueExclude
      Specify field value combination(s) to be excluded from the uniqueness constraint.

      The specified values must Strings containing comma-separated encodings of the associated fields.

      Unlike the field values used with @JField.uniqueExclude(), the field values contained here are the self-delimiting string forms.

      For some encodings this makes a difference: e.g., String values must be surrounded by double quotes. For example: 

       @PermazenType(compositeIndexes =
  @JCompositeIndex(name = "firstAndLast", fields = { "lastName", firstName" },
                      unique = true, uniqueExclude = "\"Unknown\", \"Unknown\""))
  public abstract class Person {

      public abstract String getLastName();
      public abstract void setLastName(String x);

      public abstract String getFirstName();
      public abstract void setFirstName(String x);
  }

      To specify a null value in the list, specify the self-delimiting string form of the null value (this is almost always the string "null"): 

       @PermazenType(compositeIndexes =
  @JCompositeIndex(name = "firstAndLast", fields = { "lastName", firstName" },
                      unique = true, uniqueExclude = "null, null"))
  public abstract class Person {

      public abstract String getLastName();
      public abstract void setLastName(String x);

      public abstract String getFirstName();
      public abstract void setFirstName(String x);
  }

      This property must be left empty when unique() is false.

      Returns:
      value combinations to exclude from the uniqueness constraint
      See Also:
      • unique()
      Default:
      {}
